question: An applicant for a Commercial Pilot License aeroplane shall have completed in aeroplanes not less than:

choices.choice: 150 hours of flight time and 100 hours as pilot-in-command
200 hours of flight time and 70 hours as pilot-in-command
200 hours of flight time and 100 hours as pilot-in-command

explanation:
For a Commercial Pilot Licence (Aeroplanes) [CPL(A)], the applicant must have:

  1. 200 hours total flight time.
  2. 100 hours as Pilot-in-Command (PIC), with 15 hours completed within six months before the application.
  3. 20 hours cross-country as PIC, including a 300 NM flight with full-stop landings at two different aerodromes.
  4. 10 hours instrument time, with up to 5 hours on an approved simulator.
  5. 5 hours night flight as PIC, including 10 takeoffs and landings, completed within six months before the application.
subject: Regulations

question: An applicant for a Commercial Pilot Licence shall hold a current

choices.choice: class medical assessment as prescribed by the state issuing the lience

explanation: A Commercial Pilot License (Aeroplane) (CPL(A)) holder must hold a current Class 1 medical assessment.
subject: Regulations

question: The privileges of the holder of a Commercial Pilot Licence-aeroplane shall be:

choices.choice: to act as pilot-in-command in any aeroplane engaged in commercial air transportation
to act as pilot-in-command in any aeroplane certificate for single pilot operation other than in commercial air transportation
to act as Pilot-in-Command of any aeroplane having an all-up-weight not exceeding five thousand seven hundred Kgs. and which is entered in the aircraft rating of his licence

explanation:
The privileges of the holder of a Commercial Pilot’s Licence shall be :-
(a) to exercise all the privileges of Private Pilot’s Licence;
(b) to act as Pilot-in-Command of any aeroplane having an all-up-weight not exceeding five thousand seven hundred Kgs. and which is entered in the aircraft rating of his licence provided that when passengers are to be carried at night, he shall have carried out within a period of six months immediately preceding the date of the intended flight not less than ten take-offs and ten landings by night as Pilot-in- Command:
(c) to act as Co-Pilot of any aeroplane where a Co-Pilot is required to be carried and which is entered in the aircraft rating of his licence: Provided that for all flights under the Instrument Flight Rules, either as Pilot-in- Command or as Co-Pilot, he shall have a current Instrument Rating:
Provided also that on attainment of the age of sixty-five years, such privileges shall be restricted to that of Private Pilot’s Licence Aeroplanes).
subject: Regulations

question: The minimum age of obtaining a PPL is:
explanation:
**Private Pilot Licence (PPL) Age Requirements:

1. The applicant must be at least 17 years old to obtain a PPL.
2. Training can begin at any age.
3. Solo flight is only permitted once the student reaches 16 years of age.
subject: Regulations

question: If the age of a CPL holder flying a single pilot helicopter for charters is more than 40 years the validity of medical is for__________.

choices.choice: 12 months if he is not carrying VIPs.

explanation: For pilots, a medical certificate is valid for 12 months up to age 60 (or age 40 if engaged in single-pilot commercial operations), and then every 6 months thereafter.
subject: Regulations

question: The holder of a commercial pilot licence, when acting as copilot of an aircraft required to be operated with a copilot, shall be entitled to be credit with not more than:

choices.choice: 40% of the copilot flight time towards the total flight time required for a higher grade of a pilot licence
50% of the copilot flight time towards the total flight time required for renewal of a commercial pilot licence
100 hours of flying time required for a higher grade of a pilot licence

explanation:
**Licence Renewal Requirements:**

1. The licence may be renewed upon submission of satisfactory evidence of the applicant:
– (a) Undergoing a medical examination.
– (b) Completing at least ten hours of flight time as Pilot-in-Command (up to 50% of flight time as Co-Pilot may count towards this requirement) within six months prior to the renewal application; or, alternatively, completing a general flying test by day and night within the same period.
– (c) Holding a current Flight Radio Telephone Operator’s Licence for onboard radio telephone operation, issued by the Director-General.
subject: Regulations

question: The duration of the period of currency of a medical assessment shall begin on the date:

choices.choice: the license is issued or renewed
reckoned from the date of medical examination
the license is delivered to the pilot.

explanation: The validity of a medical assessment begins from the date of the medical examination.
subject: Regulations

question: Which of the following Annexes to the Chicago convention contains minimum specifications for a crew licence to have International validity?
explanation: Annex 1 contains Standards and Recommended Practices adopted by the International Civil Aviation Organization as the minimum standards for personnel licensing, including requirements for licenses and ratings for aviation personnel.
subject: Regulations

question: The applicant to exercise the functions of an Instrumental Flight Rating in _____ aeroplanes shall prove, according to ANNEX 1, PERSONNEL LICENSING, his/her capability to pilot such aircraft only by instrumental rules and an engine________
explanation:
For the Instrument Rating (Aeroplane) (IR(A)):

  • Knowledge Requirements: The applicant must have knowledge relevant to IFR operations, aligned with the privileges of the rating.
  • Skill Requirements: The applicant must demonstrate proficiency in operating multi-engine aeroplanes solely by instruments, including handling one engine inoperative if the pilot intends to fly IFR in such aircraft.
  • Synthetic Trainers: Regulations allow the use of synthetic training devices to meet skill demonstration requirements.
subject: Regulations

question: The privileges of the holder of a Private Pilot’s Licence shall be to act as

choices.choice: Pilot-in-command or as Co-pilot of any aeroplane provided no passengers are carried
Pilot-in -command or as Co-pilot of any aeroplane and carry passengers therein with out remunerations
Pilot-in -command or as Co-pilot of an aeroplane employed on aerial work for remuneration

explanation:
The privileges and limitations of a Private Pilot’s Licence (PPL) holder:

  1. Non-Commercial Use: The PPL holder can act as Pilot-in-command or Co-pilot, but not for hire or any form of remuneration.
  2. Night Flying: Passengers may be carried at night only if the PPL holder has a valid night rating and has completed at least five take-offs and landings by night as Pilot-in-command within the preceding six months.
  3. Instrument Flight Rules (IFR): Flights under IFR are only permitted if the PPL holder possesses a valid Instrument Rating.
subject: Regulations

question: When the holders of aircraft transport pilot licenses aeroplane and helicopter have passed their 40th birthday the medical examination shall be reduced to:

choices.choice: 6 months for single crew commercial operations

explanation:
A Class 1 medical certificate is valid for a specific period, depending on the pilot’s age and the type of operations they perform:

  • 12 months for pilots under 40 years old
  • 6 months for pilots 40 years and over conducting single-pilot commercial air transport operations carrying passengers
  • 6 months for pilots over 60 years old
subject: Regulations

question: An applicant for a Commercial Pilot Licence-aeroplane shall have completed not less than….hours of cross country flight time as pilot-in-command including a cross country flight totaling not less than….km(….NM), in the course of which full stop landings at two different aerodromes shall be made. The hours and distance referred are:
explanation:
For a Commercial Pilot License:

  1. Minimum 200 hours of total flight time.
  2. At least 100 hours as Pilot-in-Command, with 15 hours within six months before application.
  3. 20 hours of cross-country as Pilot-in-Command, including one 300NM(540 km) flight with landings at two different aerodromes.
  4. 10 hours of instrument time, with up to 5 hours on a simulator.
  5. 5 hours of night flight, including 10 takeoffs and 10 landings as Pilot-in-Command, within six months before application.
subject: Regulations

question: An applicant for an Airline Transport Pilot Licence shall have completed in aeroplanes not less than:

choices.choice: 100 hours of instrument time, of which not more than 50 hours may be instrument ground time
150 hours of instrument time, of which not more than 75 hours may be instrument ground time
100 hours of instrument time, of which not more than 30 hours may be instrument ground time

explanation: One hundred hours of instrument time under actual or simulated instrument conditions of which not less than fifty hours shall be in actual flight.
subject: Regulations

question: Type ratings shall be established

choices.choice: for any type of aircraft whenever considered necessary by the authority
only aircraft certificated for operation with a minimum crew of at least two pilots

explanation:
Type Ratings are required for:

– Each type of multi-pilot aeroplane;
– Each type of single-pilot, multi-engine aeroplane with turbojet or turboprop engines;
– Each type of single-pilot, single-engine aeroplane with a turbojet engine;
– Any other type of aeroplane, if deemed necessary by the authority.
subject: Regulations

question: A applicant for the ______ licences shall have the ability to speak and understand the English language used for radiotelepohony communications to the level of proficiency specified by the Director General.

choices.choice: PPL, CPL,ATPL, Flt Navigator and Flt Engg

explanation: An applicant for the PPL, CPL, ATPL, Flt Navigator, Flt Engg, ATC and Aeronautical Station Operators licences shall have the ability to speak and understand the English language used for radiotelephony communications to the level of proficiency specified by the Director General.
subject: Regulations

question: An applicant for a Commercial Pilot Licence shall have completed in aeroplanes not less than:

choices.choice: 20 hours of instrument instruction time of which not more than 10 hours may be instrument ground time
20 hours of instrument instruction time of which not more than 5 hours may be instrument ground time
not less than ten hours of instrument time of which not more than five hours may be on an approved simulator

explanation:
For a Commercial Pilot Licence (Aeroplanes) [CPL(A)], the applicant must have:

  1. 200 hours total flight time.
  2. 100 hours as Pilot-in-Command (PIC), with 15 hours completed within six months before the application.
  3. 20 hours cross-country as PIC, including a 300 NM flight with full-stop landings at two different aerodromes.
  4. 10 hours instrument time, with up to 5 hours on an approved simulator.
  5. 5 hours night flight as PIC, including 10 takeoffs and landings, completed within six months before the application.
subject: Regulations

question: The applicant for an Airline Transport Pilot License shall have completed In aeroplanes not less than ….hours of cross-country flight time, including not less than …. hours of flight time by night as Pilot-in-Command or as Co-Pilot performing, under the supervision of a pilot who fulfills the flying experience requirements of a check pilot, the duties and functions of a pilot-in-command.
subject: Regulations

question: The holder of a pilot’s licence should inform the Authority of any illness which they are suffering which involves incapacity to undertake those functions to which the licence relates throughout a period of a certain number of days or more. The number of days is:
explanation:
1. A licence holder shall not exercise licence privileges without passing a fresh medical exam if:
– (a) He has a sickness or injury causing incapacity for 15 days or more.
– (b) He has an injury from any accident that could impair his duty efficiency.

2. The licence holder or employer must notify the Director-General immediately of relevant sickness or injury details.

3. A disqualified licence is deemed invalid until the holder passes a fresh medical examination.

4. A licence holder shall not exercise privileges if aware of physical deterioration below the required standard.
subject: Regulations

question: The holder of a commercial pilot licence when as Co-Pilot performing under the supervision of a pilot who fulfills the flying experience requirements of a check pilot, the duties and functions of a pilot-in-command shall be entitled to be entitled to be credited:

choices.choice: in full with his flight time but not more than 300 hours towards the total time required for a higher grade of pilot licence
50% of the flight time towards the total time required for higher grade of pilot licence in accordance with the requirements of the licensing authority
in full with his flight time towards the total time required for higher grade of pilot licence

explanation: Where an aeroplane is required to be operated with a co-pilot in accordance with the provisions of the Flight Manual of the aeroplane, not more than fifty percent of the co-pilot flight time shall be credited towards the total flight time required for the issue of the licence, but not more than fifty percent of the co-pilot flight time under supervision shall be credited towards pilot-in-command flight experience required for issue of the licence, and full credit for such flight time shall be given towards total flight time required for issue of the licence.
subject: Regulations

question: For Commercial Pilot Licence aeroplane the applicant shall have completed in aeroplanes not less than…. if the privileges of the licence are to be expected at:

choices.choice: 5 hours of night flight time including 3 take-offs and 3 landings as pilot-in-command
5 hours of night flight time including 5 take-offs and 5 landings as pilot-in-command
5 hours of night flight time including 10 take-offs and 10 landings as pilot-in-command

explanation:
For a Commercial Pilot Licence (Aeroplanes) [CPL(A)], the applicant must have:

  1. 200 hours total flight time.
  2. 100 hours as Pilot-in-Command (PIC), with 15 hours completed within six months before the application.
  3. 20 hours cross-country as PIC, including a 300 NM flight with full-stop landings at two different aerodromes.
  4. 10 hours instrument time, with up to 5 hours on an approved simulator.
  5. 5 hours night flight as PIC, including 10 takeoffs and landings, completed within six months before the application.
subject: Regulations

question: To be able to execute a public transport flight, the minimum and maximum age (with ATPL) is:
explanation: An applicant for an ATPL(A) must be at least 21 years of age, and a pilot who has reached the age of 65 shall not act as a pilot of an aircraft engaged in commercial air transport.
subject: Regulations

question: An applicant holding a private or commercial pilot license aeroplane for the issue of an instrument rating, shall have completed…. hours of cross-country flight time as pilot-in-command of aircraft in categories acceptable to the licensing Authority
explanation:
Experience:

The applicant must provide evidence of satisfactory completion as a pilot of an aeroplane, specifically:

(i) A minimum of 100 hours of flight time as a Pilot-in-Command, including at least 50 hours of cross-country flight time.

(ii) At least 40 hours of instrument time, with no more than 20 hours of this being instrument ground time. Additionally, a minimum of 5 hours of instrument time must have been completed within the six months immediately before the date of application for the Instrument Rating.
subject: Regulations

question: The International Civil Aviation Convention Annex containing standards and recommended practices for Personnel Licensing is:
explanation:
1. Annex 1 – Personnel Licensing
  2. Annex 2 – Rules of the Air
  3. Annex 3 – Meteorological Service for International Air Navigation
  4. Annex 4 – Aeronautical Charts
  5. Annex 5 – Units of Measurement to be Used in Air and Ground Operations
  6. Annex 6 – Operation of Aircraft
  7. Annex 7 – Aircraft Nationality and Registration Marks
  8. Annex 8 – Airworthiness of Aircraft
  9. Annex 9 – Facilitation
  10. Annex 10 – Aeronautical Telecommunications
  11. Annex 11 – Air Traffic Services
  12. Annex 12 – Search and Rescue
  13. Annex 13 – Aircraft Accident and Incident Investigation
  14. Annex 14 – Aerodromes
  15. Annex 15 – Aeronautical Information Services
  16. Annex 16 – Environmental Protection
  17. Annex 17 – Security: Safeguarding International Civil Aviation Against Acts of Unlawful Interference
  18. Annex 18 – The Safe Transport of Dangerous Goods by Air
  19. Annex 19 – Safety Management
subject: Regulations

question: The age of an applicant for a Commercial Pilot Licence shall not be less then:
explanation: An applicant for a Commercial Pilot License (Aeroplane) (CPL(A)) must be at least 18 years of age.
subject: Regulations
